Medfield's actual die size is about the same as Tegra 3 (~65 sq mm) and unlike Nvidia it can make that size of mobile die profitably. The more Tegras Nvidia makes the more money it loses, funny that for a supposedly high margin product ;-).

Message.Title: First Intel Motorola phone lauching in September !!!!
Message.Msg: London Lanuch....right in Getanid61's grill. LOL Motorola's Intel phone set for September launch Motorola's invite suggests there will be at least one handset reveal using Intel's technology Google's Motorola unit has confirmed plans to release its first smartphone powered by an Intel chip. The firm will unveil the device in London on 18 September. Intel chips are already used in phones made by Lava, Lenovo and Gigabyte. But the news marks a significant step in efforts by Google, which also makes the bestselling Android system, to crack the smartphone market. The unveiling follows a string of announcements from other tech firms. Earlier this week LG announced its new top-end model, the Optimus G. The South Korean firm was the first company to show off a prototype handset powered by an Intel chip, but it never released the model.

Message.Title: Intel: Bulls and Bears Pile Up Estimate Cuts, Q3 Miss Possible
Message.Msg: This latest negative bout kicked off last week with a note to clients on Thursday from Davenport & Co.’s Drake Johnstone, who reiterated a Neutral rating on the shares, writing that the company may miss the consensus for this quarter of $14.25 billion in revenue and 65 cents a share in profit, given weak PC sales reported by Dell (DELL) last Tuesday, and by Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) last Wednesday. Johnstone is modeling $13.8 billion and 57 cents, and he cut his Q4 estimate to $14.4 billion and 65 cents, below the consensus $15.2 billion and 71 cents. Johnston adds that in his opinion, “many consumers and businesses are purchasing smart phones and tablets instead of PCs.” Then this morning, Citigroup‘s Glen Yeung reiterated a Buy rating on Intel, but cut his target price by $2 to $32, writing that “the potential for pre-announcement is high,” in his view, given that amidst a generally “stable” semiconductor market, “One exception is the PC supply chain that continues to deteriorate, driven by a combination of poor macro conditions, tablet cannibalization, and a pause before the Windows 8 launch.” It’s unlikely the PC market will live up to Intel’s view for year shipment growth in the “low single digits” on a percentage basis. Yeung cites the same poor Dell and HP results, and weakness reported by notebook makers such as Quanta and Wistron. Yeung now models Q3 revenue of $13.78 billion, down from $14.2 billion previously, and 55 cents, down from 60 cents. And for Q4 he sees revenue of $14.19 billion, down from $14.78 billion. Yeung also cut his 2013 revenue estimate by over a billion dollars, to $57.1 billion. JMP Securities’s Alex Gauna, who has a Market Outperform rating on the shares, and a $33 price target, today cut his full-year EPS estimate to $2.35 froma prior $2.55, on revenue of $54.9 billion, which is below the consensus $55.82 billion and $2.41 per share. Writes Gauna, things that Intel can control, such as its manufacturing prowess, are offset by the prospect that Microsoft‘s (MSFT) next version of Windows, “Windows 8,” won’t really lift PC sales: Our contacts are incrementally less optimistic about Windows 8 as a near-term catalyst in light of already slow PC demand trends, continuing macroeconomic uncertainty, and greater momentum behind smartphones and tablets. Somewhat offsetting these downside risks to Intel is its freedom of pricing, stemming from the lack of any meaningful competition from AMD (AMD) and the cost benefits it should be incurring from better 22nm fab loading and graphics market share gains, along with successful Ivy Bridge integration. We also believe Data Center (server) demand trends are healthy. Gauna thinks this quarter will miss estimates, with projection for $13.95 billion and 58 cents a share.

Message.Title: Letter to Piper Jaffray
Message.Msg: Mr. Andrew S. Duff Chairman and CEO, 800 Nicollet Mall Suite 800 Minneapolis, MN 55402 Dear Mr. Duff, It is with great dismay that I have watched Piper Jaffray engage in what appears to be a continuous campaign to negatively impact the stock price of one of America’s great businesses and success stories – Intel. Piper Jaffray through its analyst Gus Richard, has expressed excessively negative opinions regarding Intel’s operations and results and enough downgrades to fill a bushel basket. This has occurred not just for a period of weeks or months but literally for a period of years. Mr. Richard appears not only to understand little about fabrication, manufacturing and the chip sector – he appears to have little or no learning curve. He not only has been wrong about Intel, he has been consistently wrong. When it becomes clear that he has been wrong, instead of correcting his views, he simply doubles down. A typical headline where Mr. Richard has talked to the press would be something like "Piper Says Supply Not a Worry, Slams Intel." This from an actual headline. This horrid record in regard to judging and predicting Intel’s performance leads one to question the internal machinations within Piper Jaffray. Are there no corrective actions within Piper Jaffray for an analyst with excessively bad judgment that continues for years? For if there are then there has to be another reason for Piper Jaffray’s constantly bearish opinions and reports to the press. There are only a couple of possibilities. My great fear is that Piper Jaffray’s opinions on Intel have nothing to do with Intel’s fundamentals or results – that Piper Jaffray’s opinions on Intel are related to some trading strategy. A phrase for this type of behavior would be "greed at the expense of ethics." Of course I have no way to know exactly why Piper Jaffray consistently bashes one of America’s great companies, one of America’s great success stories and a company that manufactures here at home. At a very difficult economic time it would seem that Piper Jaffray would attempt to assist in an economic recovery. It appears to me that Goldman is engaging in activities that are as a minimum ethically distasteful and that additionally work against US economic recovery. A review of Intel’s PE ratio clearly demonstrates that the company has been valued far below that of an average S&P 500 while producing substantially better results. It appears to me that Piper Jaffray has had a significant role in this valuation with its constant negative views, downgrades and press releases. It also appears to me that Piper Jaffray’s efforts in regards to Intel are being mirrored by a number of other key Wall Street firms. I don’t know why anyone with access to information would attempt to present such a biased viewpoint for this extended period of time. I therefore request that you conduct a full investigation of Piper Jaffray’s trading, analyzing and reporting activities in regards to Intel. And that you report back to Intel shareholders exactly why Piper Jaffray has supported market views of Intel that are not substantiated by facts or actual performance. Until such time as you do, I will ask others to make this same request of you. And I will encourage everyone I know to stop doing business with Piper Jaffray until said report is issued. Intel shareholders and investors have had enough of this behavior. We want explanations. Sincerely

Message.Title: Trefis Values Intel at $31.94 (updated 8/2)
Message.Msg: POTENTIAL UPSIDE & DOWNSIDE TO TREFIS PRICE Below are key drivers of Intel's value that present opportunities for upside or downside to the current Trefis price estimate for Intel: Notebook Processors •Notebook Processor Average Pricing: Currently we forecast this figure to decline from an estimated $122 in 2011 to about $108 by end of our forecast period resulting from increased competition from AMD & ARM-based players in the future. However if innovations such as Sandy Bridge can improve the average price for Intel's notebook processors to about $130 by end of our forecast period, there can be more than 5% upside to our price estimate. On the other hand there could be a downside of a similar order if the average price were to dip down to as low as $96 by end of our forecast period, a level seen during the recessionary period of 2009. Server Processors •Intel's Server Processor Market Share: We estimate that this figure will decline from an estimated 94.5% in 2011 to 79.3% by end of our forecast period. However if Intel's server processor share goes down to historical levels of 75% seen in 2007, there can be a mild downside. On the other hand, there can be slight upside if Intel can maintain its current position.

Message.Title: AMD Poaches Its New Chief GPU Architect from Intel, Targets GPGPU and HPC
Message.Msg: AMD Poaches Its New Chief GPU Architect from Intel, Targets GPGPU and HPC There's no denying that AMD is in the process of renewing its engineering team. After the new management settled in place, the focus shifted towards its weakened engineering. Over the past couple of years, the company lost an insurmountable amount of talent, including the majority of CPU and GPU architects. The fightback, as our senior ranked AMD source told us - started with the arrival of Jim Keller from Apple. The naming caught our Intel sources off-guard, who openly admitted that Jim Keller is one of the very best, if not the best CPU architect in the world. Today's announcement presents a surprise as well, as AMD announced that John Gustafson joined the company as the Senior Fellow and Chief Product Architect for Graphics Business Unit.

Message.Title: Intel and VMware (Mercedes and BMW)
Message.Msg: Intel collaborates with VMware on cloud security. Intel (INTC) announced a new collaboration with Vmware (VMW) and will deliver a platform for trusted cloud that combines Intel Trusted Execution Technology (Intel TXT) with the new release of VMware’s vSphere 5.1. With hardware-enhanced security capabilities integrated into the processor, Intel TXT combined with VMware vSphere 5.1 will provide a hardened and high-integrity platform to run business-critical applications in private and public cloud environments. ”Intel TXT provides hardware enforcement to help overcome some of the most challenging aspects of cloud security, including detection and prevention of bios attacks and evolving forms of stealthy malware, such as rootkits,” said Jason Waxman, general manager, Intel Cloud Infrastructure Group. “VMware vSphere 5.1 support of TXT is essential to building a foundation of trust in virtualized infrastructures and the cloud and is ready for deployment.”

Message.Title: Xeon Phi to blow doors off of AMD Bulldozer AND even Sandy Bridge!
Message.Msg: news.techeye.net/chips/intel-spills-the-beans-on-xeon-phi Intel has broke its silence on its forthcoming Xeon Phi processor which is supposed to hit the shops later this year. Although Chipzilla is not mentioning the speed of the chip it is starting to talk about some of its design decisions that it believes will make the Xeon Phi coprocessor a top HPC accelerator. Spilling some of the beans at Hot Chips was George Chrysos, who was the chief architect of Knights Corner. He said that Knights Corner microarchitecture aimed to pack a lot of number-crunching into a power-efficient package. It did this by sticking a vector processor onto a bare-bones x86 core. Chrysos said that just two percent of the Knights Corner die is dedicated to decoding x86 instructions. The rest of the chip is devoted to the L1 and L2 caches, the memory I/O, and the 512-bit vector unit. This is the biggest vector unit developed by Intel and each one can manage 8 double precision or 16 single precision SIMD operations per clock cycle. Xeon Sandy Bridge and AMD Bulldozer can only manage half of that and since there will be 50-plus cores, that means that Knight's Corner can manage 400 double precision flops per cycle. On a 2 GHz processor, that works out at 800 gigaflops and since Intel is using 22nm technology process it is going to be much more than that. Chrysos added that the design uses other HPC features. There is a math accelerator called the Extended Map Unit. This does polynomial approximations of transcendent functions like square roots, reciprocals, and exponents to speed up execution of these functions in hardware. It still lacks a device to remove stones from horses' hooves or a divide by your shoe size capability. Also under the bonnet is a scatter-gather capability better known as a vector addressing or vector I/O. This improves storing and fetching of data from non-contiguous memory addresses. Chrysos told HPC Wire that the Knights Corner cache will incorporate cache coherency in hardware but will be extended to handle lots of cores. On Knights Corner, L2 cache is 512 KB per core which is twice the size of those on the Sandy Bridge Xeons. There is a translation lookaside buffer to speed address translation, tag directories to look at all of the cores' L2 caches, and a Dcache capability to simultaneously load and store 512 bits per clock cycle. Chrysos claims that these cache features have increased per core performance by an average of 80 percent.

Message.Title: A lot of talk, but no real new product that turns on investors
Message.Msg: Intel just can't seem to put out a new product like Apple does. They talk like they are way ahead of everybody in their business, but never really excite the investors or the public. Topic.Title: Anyone have any guess on how low intc will go.

Message.Msg: flumoxed11 is another INTC pumper. HPQ, DELL and AMD are at multi-year lows yet this #$%$ thinks for some reason INTC will outperform the market. They are conjoined to the PC market whether these idiots want to believe it or not. I sold the last remaining shares I owned (core holding) of this company at $25.50. Fact of the matter is Intel (sad to say) is a has been and it appears to me that management has completely missed the boat on mobile. They underestimated the demand. I remember when I posted I had bought a 64GB HPQ tablet for $100 and this lucy clown laughed and said i was a fool, that tablets were stupid and there would be no demand. So it appears that more than one idiot was fooled by the demand of mobile products. Just be honest with yourself about this company. They have great CPU's, top of the line but the demand for them are falling on a daily basis. 08/29/2012 herbal_dude predicts Intel will warn for the current quarter. Mark it.
